'''Green Dot Bystander Intervention''' is a [[bystander education]] approach that aims to prevent violence with the help of bystanders. It is built on the premise that violence can be measurably and systematically reduced within a community.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /> Bystander intervention as a way of [[violence]] prevention programs are becoming popular within society.<ref name=":7" /> Its mission is to reduce [[Violence against women|power based-violence]] by being a proactive bystander and a reactive bystander.<ref name=":8">"Title IX." ''End Rape On Campus''. End Rape On Campus. Web. http://endrapeoncampus.org/title-ix/</ref><ref name=":0">"The Green Dot Etc. Overview." ''Green Dot Etcetera''. Green Dot Etcetera Inc, 2010. Web. https://www.livethegreendot.com/</ref>
== History == The Green Dot Bystander Intervention Program was founded by Dr. Dorothy Edwards.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> The program trains people about [[sexual assault]] and [[domestic violence]] on college campuses, primary and secondary schools, and communities. It develops and offers training for sexual assault and domestic violence.<ref name=":4" /> The method teaches students to intervene by using the 3 D's: Direct, Delegating the responsibility to others, and creating a Distraction to defuse a potentially dangerous situation.<ref name=":4" /> As described by Green Dot an example of this is in a situation at a party, intervening could mean that instead of calling out an inebriated student, an individual can create a distraction by "accidentally" spilling their drink on a potential aggressor.<ref name=":4" />
Dr. Dorothy Edwards is the founder of the Green Dot Bystander Intervention program. Prior to creating the program Dorothy Edwards worked as the [[University of Kentucky student life|University of Kentucky's]] Violence Intervention and Prevention Director where she discovered that individuals were not sure how to respond when witnessing a potential [[sexual assault]].<ref name=":5" /> In her first year of running the program she trained 10 individuals, but by the time she left the [[University of Kentucky]] she was training 3,500 students and volunteers.<ref name=":5" /> The initiative led by Dr. Edwards was supported by a new focus on [[White House Task Force to Protect Students from Sexual Assault|bystanders in The White House]]. Green Dot, Bringing in the Bystander, and [[Futures Without Violence|Coaching Boys Into Men]] are preventative bystander programs that have begun to make cultural changes.
=== Title IX === [[Title IX]] of the [[Education Amendments of 1972|1972 Education Amendment]] is a tool meant to combat campus violence. The law requires colleges and universities to fight [[gender-based violence]], [[harassment]], and respond to the needs of survivors promoting equal educational access.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":11">"Title IX in Detail." ''Know Your IX: Empowering Students to Stop Sexual Violence.'' http://knowyourix.org/title-ix/title-ix-in-detail/</ref><ref name=":12">"Sexual Harassment & Assault." ''National Women's Law Center''. National Women's Law Center, 2015. Web. http://www.nwlc.org/our-issues/education-%2526-title-ix/sexual-harassment-%2526-assault</ref>
=== Sexual assault in education === [[Sexual violence]] in schools and on campuses is a pressing civil rights issue.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":11" /> According to the National Women's Law Center students who suffer from [[sexual assault]] and [[harassment]] are deprived the liberty of equal education.<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":12" /> A majority of sexual assaults involving college students also involve drugs and alcohol.<ref name=":8" /> A female or male who is incapacitated due to drugs and alcohol is legally incapable of giving consent and someone who has sex with an incapacitated person can be prosecuted for [[rape]].<ref name=":9" />
== Purpose == The goal of Green Dot is to implement a [[bystander intervention]] strategy that prevents and reduces power-based personal violence.<ref name=":5">Cherkis, Jason, and Ryan Grim. "Here's How You Can Help Stop A Sexual Assault Before It Happens." ''The Huffington Post'' 9 July 2015, Politics sec. Web. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/07/08/bystander-intervention_n_7758118.html</ref><ref name=":4">Boyington, Briana. "What Families Should Know About Bystander Intervention." ''U.S. News'' 27 Oct. 2014, Colleges sec. Web. https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2014/10/27/what-families-should-know-about-bystander-intervention</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> [[Violence against women|Power-based violence]] includes: [[sexual violence]], [[domestic violence]], [[Dating abuse|dating violence]], [[stalking]], [[child abuse]], [[elder abuse]], and [[bullying]]. The curriculum is created from the concepts and lessons learned through research and theory across disciplines including: [[violence against women]], diffusion of innovation, [[public health]], [[Social networking service|social networking]], [[psychology]], [[Bystander effect|bystander dynamics]], perpetration, and marketing/advertising.<ref name=":4" /><ref>"The Green Dot Etc. Philosophy." ''Green Dot Etcetera''. Green Dot Etcetera Inc, 2010. Web. https://www.livethegreendot.com/</ref><ref name=":6" />
A Green Dot is a behavior, choice, or action that promotes safety for everyone. It communicates intolerance for [[sexual violence]], [[Dating abuse|dating violence]], and [[stalking]].<ref name=":7">"UCI Green Dot." ''University of California''. University of California, 4 Nov. 2015. Web. http://www.studentaffairs.uci.edu/greendot/whatisagreendot.php</ref><ref name=":6">Coker, A. L., P. G. Cook-Craig, C. M. Williams, B. S. Fisher, E. R. Clear, L. S. Garcia, and L. M. Hegge. "Evaluation of Green Dot: An Active Bystander Intervention to Reduce Sexual Violence on College Campuses." ''Violence Against Women'' 17.6 (2011): 777-96. Print.</ref> The goal is to promote safety on college campuses.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":0" />
== Training == Green Dot develops programs, strategies, curriculum, and training courses designed to address power-based personal violence across environments.<ref name=":7" /> Training strategies include: strategic planning, bystander mobilization, communication, and [[Coalition|coalition building]].<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":10">"Green Dot Faculty & Staff Toolkit." ''University of Portland''. Office on Violence Against Women. Web. http://www.up.edu/showimage/show.aspx?file=21219</ref> The program provides training courses for leadership and professionals that focus on the core areas necessary for successful implementation of the program.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":9">Smith, Carol. "A Dangerous Mix: Drinking, Sex, and College Students." ''InvestigateWest''. InvestigateWest, 2010. Web. http://invw.org/2010/02/25/940/</ref><ref name=":1">"The Green Dot Etc. Training." ''Green Dot Etcetera''. Green Dot Etcetera Inc, 2010. Web. https://www.livethegreendot.com/</ref>
The Green Dot bystander program uses four training modules to educate bystanders on their impact. # The first module provides bystanders with an overview of the strategy, where key definitions and strategies are discussed.<ref name=":2">"An Overview of the Green Dot Strategy." ''California Coalition Against Sexual Assault (CALCASA)''. California Coalition Against Sexual Assault. Web. http://www.calcasa.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Curriculum-Summary.pdf</ref><ref name=":10" /> # The second module reviews the observable behaviors associated with the major forms of power-based violence and educates about how to recognize potential dangerous or harmful situations.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /> # Module three educates bystanders on obstacles within themselves that stop them from intervening. #* There are three major categories of influence it uses:<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /> #** The categories are personal, relationship, and general issues, which impact the way in which individuals intervene.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":1" /> Personal characteristics may include being shy, fearful, or uncertain and not wanting to risk embarrassment.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":1" /> Relationship characteristics involve not wanting to upset friends or a party policer.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":1" /> General issues include the belief that someone else will intervene, the risk of embarrassment, or creating a scene.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":1" /> # Module four focuses on building skills and generating confidence in the performance of the program. #* There are two types of Green Dots: proactive and reactive. The goal of proactive Green Dots is to set the two norms that are communicated: violence will not be tolerated and everyone is expected to do his or her part to contribute to fostering a safe community. Reactive Green Dots are done in reaction to seeing concerning behavior or potential dangers, either to stop them from happening or decrease the likelihood they will get worse.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" />
The heart of the Green Dot Bystander Intervention program are the 3 D's: direct,<ref name=":7" /> distract,<ref name=":7" /> and delegate.<ref name=":7" /> Direct interaction with the potential perpetrator or victim can be used to address concern.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /> Through Distraction a [[wikt:bystander|bystander]] can create a diversion to diffuse the potentially problematic situation.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /> Lastly, through delegation a bystander can ask for someone else to help intervene in the situation.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" /> The 3 D's work in situations of high risk to act as reactive Green Dots.<ref name=":7" />
Examples of proactive Green Dots are creating social media campaigns, checking-in with friends, promoting awareness, and hosting green dot sports games.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" />
Examples of reactive Green Dots include: ''directly'' confronting a situation, ''distracting'' by changing the conversation and the energy of the interaction or by distracting the individuals, or ''delegating'' by finding someone who will be more successful in fixing the problem (bar tender, other friends, police offer, etc.)<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":10" />
=== Case studies ===
Ann Coker at the [[University of Kentucky|University of Kentucky's Center for Research on Violence Against Women]] (CRVAW) led a study pertaining to the effectiveness at Green Dots' reduction of sexual violence. In the study, CRVAW found a greater than 50% reduction in the self-reported frequency of [[Sexual violence|sexual violence perpetration]] by students at schools that received Green Dot training.<ref name=":3">Hautala, Keith. "'Green Dot' Effective at Reducing Sexual Violence." ''University of Kentucky News: UKNOW''. College of Arts and Sciences, 10 Sept. 2014. Web. http://uknow.uky.edu/content/green-dot-effective-reducing-sexual-violence</ref> The CRVAW study also found a 40% reduction in self-reported frequency of total violence perpetration including [[sexual violence]], [[sexual harassment]], [[stalking]], and [[dating violence]].<ref name=":3" /> Ann Coker, and the CRVAW team identify violence prevention as a public health priority.<ref name=":3" />
A recent study of 2,504 college undergraduate students between 18 and 24 looked at the impact of bystander intervention on college campuses. The study found that 46% of the students surveyed had heard a Green Dot speech on their college campus. Out of the sample size surveyed, only 14% had received active bystander training in the past two years. Students trained in Green Dot bystander intervention reported engaging in significantly more bystander behaviors and observing more self-reported active bystander behaviors compared to non-trained students. Those receiving bystander intervention training appeared to report more active bystander behaviors than those simply hearing a Green Dot speech, and both intervention groups reported more observed and active bystander behaviors than non-exposed students.<ref>Coker, A. L., P. G. Cook-Craig, C. M. Williams, B. S. Fisher, E. R. Clear, L. S. Garcia, and L. M. Hegge. "Evaluation of Green Dot: An Active Bystander Intervention to Reduce Sexual Violence on College Campuses." ''Violence Against Women'' 17.6 (2011): 777-96.</ref>

'''Hermann Reinheimer''' (born, 1872) was a British [[biologist]] and early science writer who proposed [[Co-operation (evolution)|cooperation in evolution]] and [[symbiogenesis]].
==Biography==
Reinheimer was a critic of Darwinian view of [[struggle for existence]]. He was the author of ''Evolution by Cooperation'' (1913) and ''Symbiogenesis'' (1915) which were influential in developing the concept of [[symbiosis]].<ref>Hankins, F. H. (1914). ''Evolution by Cooperation by Hermann Reinheimer''. ''[[The Journal of Race Development]]''. Vol. 5, No. 1. p. 123.</ref><ref>Bowler, Peter J. (2001). ''Reconciling Science and Religion: The Debate in Early-Twentieth-Century Britain''. University of Chicago Press. p. 145. {{ISBN|0-226-06858-7}}</ref> According to science historian [[Jan Sapp]] "Reinheimer is virtually unknown among contemporary biologists and historians."<ref>Sapp, Jan (1994). ''Evolution by Association : A History of Symbiosis: A History of Symbiosis''. Oxford University Press. pp. 60-61. {{ISBN|0-19-508821-2}}</ref>
In 1915, Reinheimer was one of the first writers to discuss [[symbiogenesis]]. However, the term was used without reference to [[Konstantin Mereschkowski]] who had previously written on the subject, leading cell biologist Francisco Carrapiço to speculate that Reinheimer was unfamiliar with his work.<ref name="Carrapiço 2015">Carrapiço, Francisco. (2015). ''Can We Understand Evolution Without Symbiogenesis?'' In Nathalie Gontier. ''Reticulate Evolution: Symbiogenesis, Lateral Gene Transfer, Hybridization and Infectious Heredity''. Springer. pp. 81-106. {{ISBN|978-3-319-16344-4}}</ref>
Reinheimer's views on symbiogenesis were seen as controversial during his time.<ref>Bio-Morality. Review of Symbiogenesis: The Universal Law Of Progressive Evolution by H. Reinheimer. ''[[The BMJ|The British Medical Journal]]''. Vol. 1, No. 2933. (Mar. 17, 1917), pp. 365-366.</ref> In 1916, American zoologist [[William Lawrence Tower]] described his book ''Symbiogenesis'' as the "least logical, worst constructed, most inaccurate and irrational book upon evolution that has happened in a long time."<ref>Tower, William L. (1916). ''Symbiogenesis: The Universal Law of Progressive Evolution. by Hermann Reinheimer''. ''[[American Journal of Sociology]]''. Vol. 21, No. 5, pp. 695-696.</ref>
Little about his life is known, he was described as living in [[Surbiton|Surbiton, London]] until the 1950s.<ref name="Carrapiço 2015"/>
==Publications==

{{for|the 2014 South African film|Impunity (film)}} '''Impunity''' means "exemption from punishment or loss or escape from fines".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/impunity |title=Free Dictionary |publisher=Free Dictionary |date= |accessdate=2009-12-23}}</ref> In the [[international law]] of [[human rights]], it refers to the failure to bring perpetrators of [[human rights violations]] to justice and, as such, itself constitutes a denial of the victims' right to [[justice]] and [[Legal remedy|redress]]. Impunity is especially common in countries that lack a tradition of the [[rule of law]], suffer from [[Political corruption|corruption]] or that have entrenched systems of [[patronage]], or where the [[judiciary]] is weak or members of the security forces are protected by special [[jurisdiction]]s or [[immunity from prosecution|immunities]].
The amended ''Set of Principles for the Protection and Promotion of Human Rights Through Action to Combat Impunity'', submitted to the [[United Nations]] [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights|Commission on Human Rights]] on 8 February 2005, defines impunity as: :"the impossibility, ''[[de jure]]'' or ''[[de facto]]'', of bringing the perpetrators of violations to account – whether in criminal, civil, administrative or disciplinary proceedings – since they are not subject to any inquiry that might lead to their being accused, arrested, tried and, if found guilty, sentenced to appropriate penalties, and to making reparations to their victims."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://derechos.org/nizkor/impu/principles.html |title=Principles for the Protection and Promotion of Human Rights Through Action to Combat Impunity |publisher=Derechos.org |date= |accessdate=2009-12-23}}</ref>
The First Principle of that same document states that: :"Impunity arises from a failure by States to meet their obligations to investigate violations; to take appropriate measures in respect of the perpetrators, particularly in the area of justice, by ensuring that those suspected of criminal responsibility are prosecuted, tried and duly punished; to provide victims with effective remedies and to ensure that they receive reparation for the injuries suffered; to ensure the inalienable right to know the truth about violations; and to take other necessary steps to prevent a recurrence of violations."
[[Truth and reconciliation commission]]s are frequently established by nations emerging from periods marked by human rights violations – [[coup d'état|coups d'état]], [[military dictatorship]]s, [[civil war]]s, etc. – in order to cast light on the events of the past. While such mechanisms can assist in the ultimate prosecution of crimes and punishment of the guilty, they have often been criticised for perpetuating impunity by enabling violators to seek protection of concurrently adopted [[amnesty law]]s.<ref>[http://ictj.org/publication/what-next-international-justice "What Next for International Justice?"]''International Center for Transitional Justice''</ref>
The primary goal of the Rome Statute of the [[International Criminal Court]], adopted on 17 July 1998 and entered into force on 1 July 2002, is "to put an end to impunity for the perpetrators" [...] "of the most serious crimes of concern to the international community as a whole".<ref>[Preamble, Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court: http://legal.un.org/icc/statute/romefra.htm]</ref>

Information Oriented Software Development is a [[software development methodology]] focused on working with [[information]] inside a computer program as opposed to working with just data. A significant difference exists between data and information.<ref>[http://www.diffen.com/difference/Data_vs_Information] Data vs. Information</ref> Information Oriented Software Development relies on data structures specifically designed to hold information, and relies on frameworks that support those data structures.<ref>[http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?InformationOriented] Information Oriented</ref> Information oriented software development focuses on the conceptual needs of users and customers rather than the data storage models and object models.
==Information data structures== Information data structures are data structures specifically intended to support information inside a computer program. Two common ones are as follows: * Data structures to support [[Fuzzy logic]]. * Data structures to support concept combinations<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gzb4-EqD76cC&pg=PR11&lpg=PR11&dq=%22combinations+of+concepts%22&source=bl&ots=ZUUJhexYzo&sig=qn-BN8YhOaU-y1-HpWgX6MONIfI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtteuvqYDOAhXBOj4KHSuzBtUQ6AEIdTAR#v=onepage&q=%22combinations%20of%20concepts%22&f=false] An Ontological and Epistemological Perspective of Fuzzy Set Theory</ref> and concept [[Permutations]].<ref>[https://wordpress.com/post/thisstack.wordpress.com/1449] Endemes are an Information Structure</ref>

[[NABC Coach of the Year]] (1988) | coaching_records = | BASKHOF_year = 2001 | CBBASKHOF_year = 2006 }} '''John Chaney''' (born January 21, 1932) is an American retired college [[basketball]] coach, best known for his success at [[Temple University]]. ==Early life and playing career== Chaney was born in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. He began his career after graduating from [[Bethune–Cookman University|Bethune–Cookman College]] and spending some time in the [[Eastern Professional Basketball League]], first with the Sunbury Mercuries from 1955 to 1963 and Williamsport Billies from 1963 to 1966. ==Coaching career== Chaney first became a basketball coach in 1963 at [[Sayre Area School District|Sayre Junior High School]] and went 59–9 in three seasons.{{cite web |last1=Cherner|first1=Reid|title=Chaney a teacher first 'who cares so much'|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/college/mensbasketball/atlantic10/2004-01-13-chaney_x.htm |website=USA Today|accessdate=April 3, 2016|date=January 13, 2004}} Inheriting a one-win team in 1966 at [[Simon Gratz High School]] in Philadelphia, Chaney compiled a 63–23 record in six seasons.{{cite web|title=John Chaney|url=http://www.phillyhall.org/inductee_profile.asp?ind=36|publisher=Philadelphia Sports Hall of Fame|accessdate=April 3, 2016}} The first collegiate position held by Chaney was at Division II [[Cheyney University of Pennsylvania|Cheyney State]]. At Cheyney, Chaney was 232–56. He won a national title in 1978.{{cite web|title=John Chaney|url=http://www.owlsports.com/sports/mbball/coach/bio.asp?COACH_ID=1943|publisher=Temple University Athletics |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060428054702/http://www.owlsports.com/sports/mbball/coach/bio.asp?COACH_ID=1943|archivedate=April 28, 2006|accessdate=April 3, 2016}} After a decade at Cheyney, Chaney moved on to Division I [[Temple Owls men's basketball|Temple]] in [[Philadelphia]].{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D02E2DE1F39F93BA2575BC0A964948260 |work=The New York Times |title=Chaney Is Named Coach at Temple |date=August 18, 1982 |accessdate=May 6, 2010}} Chaney built a reputation as a tough coach who always demanded excellence on and off the court. He was well known for his early-morning practices, [[match-up zone defense]], tough non-conference scheduling, and winning basketball teams. Chaney won a total of 741 career games. He took Temple to the NCAA tournament 17 times. His 1987–88 Owls team entered the NCAA tournament ranked #1 in the country, and he reached the Elite Eight on five different occasions. In 2001, Chaney was elected to the [[Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame]]. On December 20, 2004, during a win over [[Princeton Tigers men's basketball|Princeton]], Chaney became the fifth active coach and 19th all-time to appear on the sidelines for 1,000 games, joining [[Lou Henson]] ([[New Mexico State Aggies men's basketball|New Mexico State]], [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball|Illinois]]), [[Bob Knight]] ([[Army Black Knights men's basketball|Army]], [[Indiana Hoosiers men's basketball|Indiana]], [[Texas Tech Red Raiders basketball|Texas Tech]]), [[Eddie Sutton]] ([[Creighton Bluejays men's basketball|Creighton]], [[Arkansas Razorbacks men's basketball|Arkansas]], [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky]], [[Oklahoma State Cowboys basketball|Oklahoma State]], [[San Francisco Dons men's basketball|San Francisco]]), and [[Hugh Durham]] ([[Florida State Seminoles men's basketball|Florida State]], [[Georgia Bulldogs basketball|Georgia]], [[Jacksonville Dolphins men's basketball|Jacksonville]]). On March 13, 2006, Chaney announced his retirement from coaching at a [[press conference]], to be effective after Temple's play in the [[National Invitation Tournament]] (NIT). [[Fran Dunphy]] was named Chaney's successor following the season. Chaney has since been inducted into the [[Philadelphia Big 5|Big 5]] Hall of Fame, which recognizes the best in Philadelphia's college basketball history. ==Controversy== On February 13, 1994, controversy ensued when he threatened to kill then-[[UMass Minutemen basketball|University of Massachusetts Amherst]] coach [[John Calipari]] at a post-game news conference, where Calipari was speaking at a podium. Chaney entered the conference mid-speech, accusing Calipari of manipulating the referees. When Calipari attempted to respond to the accusations, Chaney yelled, "Shut up goddammit!", and proceeded to charge the stage, before being stopped by security. While being held back, Chaney shouted, "When I see you, I'm gonna kick your ass!" As security restrained Chaney, he repeatedly yelled, "I'll kill you!" and angrily admitted telling his players to "knock your fucking kids in the mouth." Chaney received a one-game suspension for the incident. The two coaches later reconciled. Chaney has recently praised Calipari's coaching ability and defended him over the [[Derrick Rose]] controversy at the [[Memphis Tigers men's basketball|University of Memphis]].{{cite news|last1=Moran|first1=Malcolm|title=COLLEGE BASKETBALL; Chaney Lambastes UMass's Calipari |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/14/sports/college-basketball-chaney-lambastes-umass-s-calipari.html|accessdate=December 30, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=February 14, 1994}}{{cite web|title=John Chaney to John Calipari: "I'll Kill You"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r6jUpHClybQ|publisher=YouTube|date=31 March 2009 |accessdate=December 30, 2017}} Chaney made headlines in 2005 after ordering backup forward Nehemiah Ingram into the game to commit hard fouls against Big 5 rival [[Saint Joseph's Hawks men's basketball|Saint Joseph]]'s in response to what he thought were several missed calls by the referees. After the game Chaney admitted to "sending a message" and stated "I'm going to send in what we used to do years ago, send in the goons."{{cite news|title=The Madness of John Chaney|url=http://www.phillymag.com/articles/2007/07/05/the-madness-of-john-chaney/ |accessdate=December 30, 2017|work=Philadelphia Magazine|date=July 5, 2007}} John Bryant of Saint Joseph's suffered a fractured arm as a result of an intentional foul. Following the incident, he suspended himself for one game, and upon hearing the severity of the injury, the university suspended him for the remainder of the regular season. Temple then later extended the suspension to the Atlantic 10 tournament. He returned for a farewell season that ended in a loss to Saint Joseph's in the A-10 Tournament. ==Coaching highlights== * Chaney has led teams to an overall record of 741–312 and 31 post season berths * Compiled a 225–59 record at Cheyney State * NCAA Division II Tournament, 1973, 1974, 1976–80, 1982 * NCAA Division II Tournament National Champions, 1978 * Division II National Coach of the Year, 1978 * State of Pennsylvania Distinguished Faculty Award, 1979 * Compiled a 516–253 record at Temple * Compiled a 296–100 Atlantic 10 Conference Regular Season Record * Won his 400th game at
